headline: Slow-Cooker Cassoulet
description: This classic French stew recipe is typically made with a variety of meats and simmered over the course of multiple days. In this easy, streamlined cassoulet, the slow cooker makes it a breeze to have a healthy dinner on the table when you get home.
name: Slow-Cooker Cassoulet
recipeIngredient: 1 pound dried great northern beans, soaked (see Tip) and drained
2 pounds pork shoulder or pork butt, trimmed and cut into 2-inch pieces

recipeInstructions.text: To prepare cassoulet: Combine beans, ham hock, onion, sliced garlic, bay leaves, thyme and salt in a 6- to 7-quart slow cooker. Add broth and juice from tomatoes (reserve the tomatoes). Nestle pork into the bean mixture.

Cook tomato paste in a small saucepan over medium-high heat, stirring constantly, until deeply browned in several spots on the bottom, 2 to 3 minutes. Add wine and bring to a boil, stirring to dissolve the tomato paste and release the browned bits from the pan. Pour into the slow cooker. Coarsely chop the reserved tomatoes and spread over the top so the beans are mostly covered.
Cook on High for 6 hours or Low for 9 hours. Remove meat from the ham hock and chop; stir back into the stew. Discard the bay leaves.

To prepare breadcrumbs: Cook oil and breadcrumbs in a large nonstick skillet over medium heat, stirring often, until starting to crisp, 10 to 15 minutes. Add minced garlic; cook, stirring often, for 2 minutes. Remove from heat and stir in parsley. Serve the breadcrumbs over the cassoulet.

review.reviewBody: This is a really delicious, comforting meal in a cold night. I made some tweaks to use what I had on hand: a ham bone instead of a ham hock and 1 pound of pork instead of the 2 pounds called for. I did the quick soak method for the beans and ended up having to cook a bit longer in the slow cooker than the specified time to get them tender. I also used dried panko breadcrumbs instead of fresh and it worked great, just cook time was a lot faster. This is all to say: a very adaptable recipe the whole family loved.

We loved it! The secret here is the ham hock & browning the tomato paste & the wine to release the brown bits!!! I used fresh thyme as fresh herbs are my favorite. I added spinach & carrots cause Iâ€™ve gotta sneak these in on the fam when I can. Served over a white wild rice blend. This is a keeper! Thank you Eating Well, I use a lot of your recipes!

This was easy enough to make, but the flavor was not that exciting to me. Maybe because I added some extra water (I was worried about the beans cooking and not having enough water... didn't seem to be a valid worry- there was plenty of liquid), but it seemed to be missing something... maybe I wanted a little more acidity? I used crushed saltines instead of breadcrumbs because it's easier... probably not as healthy as whole wheat though. :)
